awd_titl_txt: NSF/FDA/SIR: Evaluating cellular integrity as a function of bioprinter nozzle geometry
awd_abstract_narration:
"Bioprinting" is an approach to assemble individual living cells to form tissue like skin or muscle, much like 3-D printing with metal or plastic to form machine parts.  This method promises to revolutionize fabrication of tissue replacements or tissue models for drug testing. A limitation of bioprinting is that individual cells are fragile and may be damaged by being squirted through a narrow tube called a capillary through a small opening.  The project proposes to measure damage to the cell membrane, internal skeleton, and DNA depending on the properties of the printing capillary.  
 
The applicants propose to address an important issue in "bioprinting", which is like 3D printing to assemble cells into tissue like skin or muscle.  The issue is that the shear forces in the narrow capillary in the print head can damage the cell membrane, cytoskeleton, and DNA in the nucleus; slowing the liquid flow in the capillary to reduce the shear force may result in an unacceptable reduction in print speed.  The applicants propose to determine the effects of shear time and changes in capillary properties on the cell damage.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF KENTUCKY RESEARCH FOUNDATION, THE

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Artificial organs enable medical researchers to test devices and drugs on human biology without endangering a person. Artificial organs often use special 3D printers to place cells into tissue structures. This project determined how much cells are damaged when they are printed into small artificial organs. Some cell damage is unavoidable, because the cells must squeeze through small nozzles as they are printed into place. The design of these nozzles impacts the amount of damage and the types of damage to the cells. The intellectual merit of this project lies determining how strong the fluid forces need to be to damage different parts of the cells.  Additionally, the project determined how longer exposure to the fluid forces increases the damage to each part of the cell. This work supports the design of better nozzles that will print healthier artificial tissues and organs. The project has significant broader impacts, including a better informed nozzle designs for the printers that are expected to make artificial tissues to accelerate drug and medical device testing. Additionally, an improved nozzle design will increase the speed of printing, potentially allowing larger healthy tissues to be printed. Beyond the scientific impacts of this project, several scholars were trained in the regulatory science that supports the rapid evaluation of drugs and devices. This training will help these researchers approach drug and device design in a way that rapidly gets the best solutions into practice. This project also exposed researchers at the US Food and Drug Administration to emerging tools in the manipulation of cells for therapeutic applications.

 


Last Modified: 12/02/2021
Modified by: Brad J Berron
